definitions.definition: to produce flames and heat

examples.text: A welcoming **fire was burning** in the fireplace.
Fires were burning all over the city.
A small candle burned brightly.
Fresh leaves will burn slowly with billows of smoke.
The fire was still burning fiercely.
The flame in the oil lamp burned steadily.

definitions.definition: to be on fire

examples.text: By nightfall the whole city was burning.
The girl ran from the burning building.
Two children were rescued from the burning car.
They called us to tell us that my aunt's house was burning.
The smell of burning rubber filled the air.

definitions.definition: to destroy, damage, injure or kill somebody/something by fire; to be destroyed, etc. by fire

examples.text: Six million acres have burned this year in the United States.
The house **burned to the ground**.
Ten people **burned to death** in the hotel fire.
to burn waste paper/dead leaves
All his belongings were burnt in the fire.
The house was **burnt to the ground** *(= completely destroyed)*.
The survivors burned the bodies of the victims of the plague.
Several protesters burned American flags.
The cigarette burned a hole in the carpet.
Joan of Arc was **burned at the stake**.
His greatest fear is of being **burnt alive**.
Many were left with no choice but to burn alive or leap to their deaths from the upper floors.
Several people were burned to death.
The building was burned to the ground.
Bishop Tunstall preached a sermon against the book, after which copies were ceremonially burnt.
She burned all his letters.

definitions.definition: if you burn a fuel, or a fuel burns, it produces heat, light or energy

examples.text: Which fuel burns most efficiently?
a furnace that burns gas/oil/coke
Some people burn calories *(= use food to produce energy)* faster than others.

definitions.definition: if food burns, or if you burn it, it is damaged by too much heat

examples.text: I can smell something burning in the kitchen.
Sorry—I burnt the toast.

definitions.definition: to be damaged or injured by the sun, heat, acid, etc.; to damage or injure somebody/something in this way

examples.text: My skin burns easily *(= in the sun)*.
fair skin that burns easily
I got badly burned by the sun yesterday.
I burnt my tongue trying to eat a hot meat pie.
The soup's hot. Don't burn your mouth.
His face had been horrifically burnt by acid.
I burned myself on the stove.

definitions.definition: if part of your body burns or is burning, it feels very hot and painful

examples.text: Your forehead's burning. Have you got a fever?
Her cheeks burned with embarrassment.
Her skin seemed to burn at his touch.
Our eyes were burning from the chemicals in the air.

definitions.definition: to produce light

examples.text: Lights were burning upstairs, but no one answered the door.
hot sunshine burning through the windows
Their torches burned brightly in the dark.

definitions.definition: to feel or show a very strong emotion or desire
definitions.sensetop: burn with somethingburn to do something

examples.text: Her eyes burned fiercely.
to be burning with rage/ambition/love
He was burning to go climbing again.
He was burning with indignation.
I could sense the anger burning slowly inside her.

definitions.definition: to move very fast in a particular direction

examples.text: The car was burning down the road.

definitions.definition: to make somebody very angry

examples.text: So you did it just to burn me?

definitions.definition: to put information onto a CD or DVD
to spend money

examples.text: The project burns £2 million a year in contractor costs.
The state has already burned through its cash reserves.

definitions.definition: to do something that makes it impossible to return to the previous situation later

examples.text: Think carefully before you resign—you don't want to burn your bridges.

definitions.definition: to become very tired by trying to do too many things and going to bed late and getting up early
to suffer as a result of doing something without realizing the possible bad results, especially in business

examples.text: He got his fingers badly burnt dabbling in the stock market.

definitions.definition: if money burns a hole in your pocket, you want to spend it as soon as you have it
to study or work until late at night
to drive very fast
to become completely burnt, especially because it has been cooked for too long

examples.text: By the time I got home, the cake was burnt to a cinder.
The tower was struck by lightning and was burned to a cinder.
I like my steak burnt to a cinder on the outside and blood red and juicy inside.

definitions.definition: to go wrong or to fail badly and suddenly

examples.text: His career crashed and burned after he threatened a journalist.
The stock markets are getting ready to crash and burn.
She continued to crash and burn through personal controversies that included driving drunk.

definitions.definition: a person thinks that other people are talking about them, especially in an unkind way

examples.text: ‘I bumped into your ex-wife last night.’ ‘I thought I could feel my ears burning!’

definitions.definition: to have so much money that you do not have to be careful with it

wordOrigin: verb Old English birnan ‘be on fire’ and bærnan ‘consume by fire’, both from the same Germanic base; related to German brennen.
